description.narrative: The aim of this project is to utilise a catalytic coalition to design and implement a unique and ambitious programme that aims to reduce the incidence of stunting among children under two years of age in two districts of Bangladesh.

mailing-address.narrative: 1 Saint Johns Lane, London EC1M 4AR, United Kingdom

Significant reduction in stunting (additional 6% points in three years) among under 2 years children in Sylhet and Moulvibazar districts of Sylhet division and catalyze support across Govt. and other stakeholders for a coordinated multisectoral approach in Sylhet and Moulvibazar districts and beyond

title.narrative: Indicator 2: Prevalence of wasting among the children under 2 years (12 to 23 months)

description.narrative: This indicator measures the percent of children 12-23 months who are acutely malnourished, as defined by a weight for height Z score < -2. Weight-for-height describes current nutritional status. A child who is more than two standard deviations below (-2 SD) the reference median for weight-for-height is considered to be too thin for his or her height, or wasted. This condition reflects acute or recent nutritional deficit. Children who are wasted are too thin for their height, and have a much greater risk of dying than children who are not wasted.

title.narrative: Indicator 1: Prevalence of stunting among the children under 2 years (12 to 23 months)

description.narrative:
Stunting refers for low “height for age” of children. Children who suffer from growth retardation as a result of poor diets or recurrent infections tend to be at greater risk for illness and death.
Stunting is the result of long-term nutritional deprivation and often results in delayed mental development, poor school performance and reduced intellectual capacity. This in turn affects economic productivity at national level. Women of short stature are at greater risk for obstetric complications because of a smaller pelvis. Small women are at greater risk of delivering an infant with low birth weight, contributing to the intergenerational cycle of malnutrition, as infants of low birth weight or retarded intrauterine growth tend be smaller as adults.

comment.narrative: Overall 50%. When stratified by poor and very poor households the percentages are respectively 47% and 54%.

title.narrative: Indicator 3: Number of districts with replicated Suchana’s best practices

description.narrative: This indicator will report that Suchana contributes to replicate its best practices in other two districts. Providing appropriate training to the relevant GoB staff of different levels, who are one of the key players in nutrition governance, is very important. Suchana will provide training to the relevant GoB staff on nutrition governance.In addition, one of the objectives of the Suchana advocacy strategy is improving capacities of GoB functionaries to replicate Suchana’s best practices in the two target districts. Through the trainings, sharing and advocacy activities Suchana will make contributions to replicate Suchana’s best practices in other (preferably adjacent) two districts.

comment.narrative: We are seeing elements of replication of Suchana best practices in multiple places.

description.narrative: Strengthened government coordination and governance for mulit-sectoral nutrition Programs at national and subnational level
Quantitative & qualitative learning paper on the cost-efficiency & cost-effectiveness of the Suchana program based on programme evidence will be shared with SMB
